Following the announcement that the UK Government would make available to Bermuda a further 29,250 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and ancillary equipment  http://web.archive.org/web/20210202001116/https://www.gov.bm/articles/government-house-advisory-pfizer-biontech%C2%A0vaccine

Bermuda’s National COVID-19 vaccination strategy has as its primary priority for the COVID-19 vaccination programme the prevention of COVID-19 mortality and the protection of health care workers, essential workers and social care staff and systems.  Secondary priorities include vaccination of those at increased risk of hospitalisation, at increased risk of exposure, and to maintain resilience in public services.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210202002109/https://www.gov.bm/vaccines

On 25 January 2021, elementary and secondary students in some regions of the province of Ontario returned to school. However, schools in the Cities of Toronto and Hamilton as well as the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Peel and York (suburban Toronto) continue to conduct classes online until at least 10 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Government of Ontario and cp24 tv news websites,  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122104517if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/statement/60033/over-100000-ontario-students-return-to-class-beginning-next-week   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125204416/https://www.cp24.com/news/students-return-to-in-class-instruction-in-seven-regions-of-province-today-1.5280563

C1 = 3T  In the 29 January 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, there was a report on the province of Ontario’s decision to return elementary and secondary students in some regions (Ottawa, southeastern Ontario including Kingston, southwestern Ontario including London) to in-class learning at school from online classes at home. However, schools in the Cities of Toronto and Hamilton as well as the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Peel and York (suburban Toronto) continue to conduct classes online until at least 10 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129181047/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-modelling-projects-continued-drop-in-cases-if-restrictions/

In the 4 February 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, there was a report on the province of Ontario’s decision to return elementary and secondary students in the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Hamilton, Halton and Durham (suburban Toronto) to in-class learning at school on 8 February from online classes at home. However, schools in Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Schools and post-secondary educational institutions are closed.” As noted on 4 February 2021 schools in Canada’s largest city Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. In the rest of Canada, elementary and secondary schools are open. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

On 19 February 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. Schools in Canada’s largest city Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York were scheduled to reopen (weather permitting) for in-school classes on 16 February. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5, “Schools and post-secondary educational institutions are closed.” See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219144150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/education/files/Education-Online-Learning-english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217021924/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-snow-disrupts-return-to-in-person-learning-in-three-ontario-covid-19/

On 26 February 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5, “the Chief Medical Officer of Health and the Provincial Government, advised that all schools would be moving to Scenario 3 - online instruction. This will continue until at least Friday, February 26, as part of province-wide efforts to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19.” See Newfoundland and Labrador English School District website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220172254/https://www.nlesd.ca/families/covid19-2021.jsp

On 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec published an updated list of businesses required to close and essential businesses allowed to operate under restricted rules. Quebec may have the most restrictive provincial policy in place now. Ontario has also closed and/or restricted business operations. Ontario and Quebec are the two most populous provinces See Government of Quebec website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125205800/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/list-commercial-enterprises/

In the 29 January 2021 print editions of English-language Canadian newspapers, a Canadian Press report quoted Quebec Premier Francois Legault’s warning that “the majority of measures will remain … such as closing non-essential businesses”. Quebec continues to enforce the most restrictive policy among Canada’s provinces and territories. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129153654/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-deaths-in-quebec-jumped-10-per-cent-in-2020-due-to-covid-19/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario (the most populous in Canada) continues to enforce closures and restrictions on non-essential businesses as do Quebec, New Brunswick and other jurisdictions. Some provinces have started a gradual reopening. See GOVERNment of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201191314/https://www.ontario.ca/page/enhancing-public-health-and-workplace-safety-measures-provincewide-shutdown  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205140421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-covid-19-cases-in-first-nations-communities-has-dropped-to/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Gym and fitness facilities, yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, arenas, dance studios and performance spaces are closed. Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service, but can offer online/telephone sales with delivery or curbside pick-up options. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed. Restaurants are closed for in-person dining. Take-out, delivery and drive-thru options are permitted. Bars, lounges, bingo halls and cinemas are closed.” Other provinces have started or announced intentions to begin a gradual reopening. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211161415/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/editorials/article-will-doug-fords-reopening-plan-be-a-booster-shot-for-the-pandemic/

On 19 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador remains at alert level 5: “Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” Non-essential businesses remain closed in Canada’s largest city Toronto, two suburban Toronto regions and a northern Ontario region pending a decision by the Ontario government. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217214201/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219151305/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-1038-new-covid-19-cases-44-additional-deaths/

On 25 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador remains at alert level 5: “Gym and fitness facilities are closed, including yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, and arenas. Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” Non-essential businesses remain closed in Canada’s largest city Toronto, a suburban Toronto region and a northern Ontario region “until March 8”. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219150436/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225163539/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-975-new-covid-19-cases-and-12-additional-deaths/

On 25 January 2021, the City of Toronto (most populous in Canada) continues to conform with the “Province-wide (Ontario) declaration of emergency …(by) extending the cancellation of City-led and City-permitted outdoor special events through March 31”. Similar policies are in place in Quebec and other provinces. See City of Toronto website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125211052/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-latest-city-of-toronto-news/affected-city-services/?accordion=events  ***Updated to also include Quebec - "Activities organized in a public place Prohibited, except for places of worship (maximum of 10 people in attendance) and funerals (a maximum of 25 people excluding the staff of the funeral establishment and volunteers inside or outside the building. Keeping an attendance register is mandatory). Moreover, no food or alcohol can be served."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210129173941/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/

C3 = 3T  On 29 January 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” The Province of Quebec and other provinces have imposed similar rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202172433/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “A Province-wide declaration of emergency is in effect. Stay home except for essential reasons. … Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” Other provinces (but not all) have imposed similar rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129185219/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

Businesses are now allowed to host events and activities. On 11 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force in the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city): “Stay home except for essential reasons. … Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” Other provinces have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia now allowing public events with restrictions. On 24 February 2021, the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city) announced “extending the cancellation of in-person City-led and City-permitted major outdoor events to July 1, including Canada Day parades, festivals and fireworks. Today’s announcement includes festivals and other large, in-person gatherings held at outdoor sites managed by the City or other public locations, such as roads, parks and civic squares.” Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia allowing public events with rules. See City of Toronto websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225045219/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210218051016/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Events-theatres-and-venues-COVID-19-prevention-guidelines.pdf

On 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec clarified that its rule limiting regular religious observance gatherings to 10 persons applies to the entire building, not each room. Other than religious settings: “Indoor or outdoor private gatherings (p)rohibited.” Quebec may have the most restrictive provincial policy in place now. Other provinces have also restricted indoor and outdoor gatherings to a maximum of 10 persons. See Government of Quebec and Montreal Gazette newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125212921/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125213115/https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/quebec-flip-flops-on-gatherings-in-places-of-worship-for-third-time-in-48-hours

On 29 January 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force:  " (1) Subject to sections 2 to 4, no person shall attend, (a)  an organized public event that is held indoors; (b)  a social gathering that is held indoors, including a social gathering associated with a gathering described in clause (d); (c)  an organized public event or social gathering of more than 5 people that is held outdoors, including a social gathering associated with a gathering described in clause (d); or (d)  a gathering of more than 10 people for the purposes of a wedding, a funeral or a religious service, rite or ceremony"  Link not archiving: https://www.ontario.ca/laws/regulation/200082/v34  ***Note updated to include bylaw link and full text on gatherings; link to Toronto website deleted as it was from November and allowed up to 10 people at outdoor events, compared to Ontario bylaw 82/20 which now only allows for 5

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Quebec continues to impose a curfew between 8 p.m. and 5 a.m except for travel to and from an essential workplace and walking a dog. No other province has a curfew. See government of Quebec website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125212921/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/confinement-in-quebec/

In the 29 January 2021 print editions of English-language Canadian newspapers, a Canadian Press report quoted Quebec Premier Francois Legault’s warning that “the majority of measures will remain … Legault singled out the province’s 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew as a measure that is “working well,” suggesting that it was likely to be among the rules that is extended..” Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129153654/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-deaths-in-quebec-jumped-10-per-cent-in-2020-due-to-covid-19/

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew. Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204194341/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-to-loosen-some-pandemic-restrictions-maintain-nighttime-curfew/

Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. On 25 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in Monteal and other southern Quebec regions and 9:30 pm to 5 am in northern and western Quebec regions where covid cases per capita are lower. As of January 25 2021, the 4 Atlantic provinces continue to require 14-day quarantine requirements on Canadians entering from another province (including other Atlantic provinces; Atlantic bubble suspended) as well as restrictions on "non-essential" travel into these provinces by non-residents. For examples, see CAN-NB and CAN_NL.   See New Brunswick website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130111953/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/travel.html  ***note updated to include New Brunswick website link

29 January was the first full day of effect in 2021 for the province of Manitoba’s requirement: “Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” Manitoba imposed a similar rule during 2020 and then relaxed the requirements gradually. The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, that now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129195407/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 5 February 2021, the province of Manitoba continued to enforce ’s requirement: “Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205145805/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 11 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “The self-isolation order continue to require that anyone entering Manitoba, regardless of whether it was from another country or another province must self-isolate for 14 days” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211182733/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 19 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164644/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 25 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which also apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164644/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224144057/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/pei-covid-travel-bubble-1.5924514

As of 25 January 2021, the government of Canada’s rules remain in place restricting non-Canadians from entering Canada except to perform “essential” work or to visit a family member who is a Canadian citizen. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114193357/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html

In a 28 January 2021 Canadian Press news service report, more coverage of whether border controls are strict enough to encourage enough Canadians to heed public health advice to limit international travel to essential trips. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210128135746/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-holiday-season-vacations-coincide-with-rise-in-covid-19-travel-related-2/

On 29 January 2021, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced an agreement with Canadian airlines to suspend flights to Mexican and Carribean destinations effective 31 January through 30 April. ‘In the coming weeks the federal government will also introduce mandatory COVID-19 testing upon arrival at airports, and this will be on top of the pre-boarding requirement for a negative COVID-19 test, Mr. Trudeau said. Following the second test, travellers will have to wait three days at a designated hotel for their test result. Mr. Trudeau said the hotel stays will cost travellers more than $2,000. If the traveller’s second test is negative, they will be able to complete their 14-day quarantine at home “under significantly increased surveillance and enforcement.”’ These measures are intended to encourage Canadians to heed public health advice against non-essential international travel. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129180239/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-federal-government-airlines-agree-to-halt-flights-to-caribbean-mexico/

On 5 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment...Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...Travellers entering Canada must, during your 14-day period while in quarantine or isolation, stay in a hotel while waiting a negative result of their molecular test.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205151123/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 11 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment...Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...Travellers entering Canada must, during your 14-day period while in quarantine or isolation, stay in a hotel while waiting a negative result of their molecular test.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211183357/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 19 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days... Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219165800/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 25 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224071107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118232215/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205194713/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219181517/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

On 25 January 2021, the Canadian Medical Association (CMA) called for “redoubling our efforts in effective … contact tracing”. This indicates that previously reported problems keeping contact tracing on pace with higher case numbers remain an issue. See CMA newswire, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125233051/https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/one-year-since-first-canadian-covid-19-case-the-cma-calls-for-a-clear-and-focused-plan-ahead-876909120.html

In a 27 January 2021 report, the Globe and Mail, Canada’s only newspaper with a national readership, reported on recent contact tracing problems in a region in the province of Ontario north of Toronto with an outbreak of cases attributed to the “British variant”. The regional public health officer “reached out to other public-health units in Ontario for assistance with contact tracing. Three have stepped up … sending a total of nine staff to help with contact tracing...Without help from the other regions, Dr. Gardner said his health unit did not have the resources to reach contacts within 24 hours.” However, redeployment of contact tracers from low-case to high-case regions is a positive initiative. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210128135316/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-cases-keep-climbing-after-ontario-long-term-care-home-struck/

In a 1 February Globe and Mail newspaper article, the reporter comments: “The Simcoe Muskoka health unit is revamping its contact tracing systems instead of relying on people who test positive for COVID-19 to track down their contacts. It is one of many regions in Canada that have significantly scaled back identifying, managing and assessing those who have been exposed because they could no longer keep up with the pace of new infections.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205202621/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-variant-in-barrie-outbreak-upends-conventional-wisdom-of/

In a 10 February Globe and Mail newspaper article, the City of Hamilton’s Medical Officer of Health laments that the province of Ontario’s “reopening plans are emerging just as her staff have recovered their ability to keep up with the task of tracing all the contacts of confirmed cases”. Since other regions have higher daily case per capita counts than Hamilton, it is probable that contact tracing delays are continuing in other parts of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211133106/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-officers-in-some-covid-19-hot-spots-push-back-against-ontarios/

As of 19 February 2021, there is not enough evidence to say that contact tracing is back to comprehensive in all regions of Canada. In a Globe and Mail newspaper opinion column, Dr. Brooks Fallis expressed dissatisfaction by urging provincial and territorial governments: “Focus contact tracing efforts on high-risk areas that continue to drive transmission and properly invest in local public health units so we can rapidly trace every contact.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217153210/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-canada-is-sleepwalking-into-a-third-wave-and-it-could-be-the-worst-one/

On 25 February 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada warned: “Any easing of public health measures must be done slowly with enhanced testing, screening, and genomic analysis to detect variants of concern. In particular, there must be sufficient contact tracing capacity”. This concern suggests that contact tracing may not be comprehensive in all regions of Canada. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225201518/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/02/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-february-25-2021.html

On 23 January 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada  repeated advice about “wearing a face mask as appropriate (including in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household)”. Most provinces have imposed such a requirement. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125231259/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/digital-resources.html

As of 29 January 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. 3T pending review of whether all provinces and territories require masks in outdoor public spaces. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  ***Review note: confirmed via subnational data that some provinces (e.g. BC) coded as 2G for masks, meaning 3T at national level still accurate

As of 5 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. With British Columbia imposing more extensive mask requirements in schools, Canada is getting closer to 3G. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205201144/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205200054/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-bc-makes-masks-in-middle-and-high-school-classrooms-mandatory/

As of 11 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces, but not all, have stringent mask requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212012948/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students. See Government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184203/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213205449/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/covid-19-bc-school-guidelines-enhanced-health-and-safety-measures-announced-1.5899483

As of 25 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students at their desks. See Government of Canada and Globe newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224134806/http://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225202506/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-covid-19-variant-in-schools-means-its-time-for-all-students-in-bc-to/

As of 25 January 1:05 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “more than 733,500 Canadians [1.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. At least 96,537 [0.25%] of Canadians are fully vaccinated, having received both required doses.” See covid19tracker.ca, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124221629/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 29 January 10:25 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 82.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 829,385 Canadians [almost 2.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 96,857 Canadians [0.25%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” Note that previous estimates of the number of Canadians fully vaccinated were incorrect due to a data reporting error by one of the provinces. Delays in vaccine delivery to Canada have resulted in first-does vaccinations being halted in the province of Alberta. In most other provinces and territories, vaccine supply is sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129155032/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129163115/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/covid-update-deena-hinshaw-alberta-1.5891450

As of 5 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 89.1% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 883,648 Canadians [2.3% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 150,807 Canadians [almost 0.4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has resulted in a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010943/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205162839/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/gov

As of today, 90.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 940,304 Canadians [almost 2.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 235,924 Canadians [0.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210211185843/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html https://web.archive.org/web/20210211190042/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 19 February 11:12AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,007,878 Canadians [2.65% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 372,911 Canadians [almost 1%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past 4 weeks. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217180702/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184842/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

The United States has restricted the entry of all foreign nationals who have passed through or have been in China, Iran, Most European Countries, UK, Ireland and Brazil in the past 14 days. Starting on January 26, all travelers (including US citizens and transit passenger) must present a negative COVID-19 viral or antigen test result issued 72 hours prior to departure or have an evidence of having contracted and recovered from COVID-19 prior to boarding the plane.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210126085827/https://www.kayak.com/travel-restrictions     On January 12, 2021, CDC announced an Order requiring all air passengers arriving to the US from a foreign country to get tested no more than 3 days before their flight departs and to present the negative result or documentation of having recovered from COVID-19 to the airline before boarding the flight. Air passengers will also be required to confirm that the information they present is true in the form of an attestation. This Order is effective as of 12:01am EST (5:01am GMT) on January 26.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126090008/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/testing-international-air-travelers.html

The United States has restricted the entry of all foreign nationals who have passed through or have been in China, Iran, Most European Countries, UK, Ireland, Brazil and South Africa in the past 14 days. Starting on January 26, all travelers (including US citizens and transit passenger) must present a negative COVID-19 viral or antigen test result issued 72 hours prior to departure or have an evidence of having contracted and recovered from COVID-19 prior to boarding the plane.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210131133052/https://www.kayak.com/travel-restrictions    http://web.archive.org/web/20210202011147/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/testing-international-air-travelers.html

However, due to surge in cases,  states like Idaho, New Hampshire, Maine, Michigan, Louisiana etc. are prioritizing cases based on age, high-risk, vulnerability and requiring people with positive cases to notify their own contacts  https://www.nashp.org/state-approaches-to-contact-tracing-covid-19/#tab-id-4     Also based on contact tracing statistics, Delaware has only traced 47% of named contacts from July to January 2021.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200516220715/https://myhealthycommunity.dhss.delaware.gov/locations/state
